channel.title: Comments on: How To Check A Site For SPDY Support With OpenSSL

item.title: By: Custom SPDY at Facebook | Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Custom SPDY at Facebook | Joseph Scott
item.description: […] making plans to retire SPDY in favor of HTTP/2 I started testing sites to see how many of them advertised support for HTTP/2. No surprise that Google […]
item.content:encoded: […] making plans to retire SPDY in favor of HTTP/2 I started testing sites to see how many of them advertised support for HTTP/2. No surprise that Google […]

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2014/12/02/how-to-check-a-site-for-spdy-support-with-openssl/#comment-4286">Daan Kortenbach</a>.
In this case it wasn't a question of if SPDY was working ( it was ), but a bug in that was allowing for a ~200ms delay in some cases.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Daan Kortenbach.

In this case it wasn’t a question of if SPDY was working ( it was ), but a bug in that was allowing for a ~200ms delay in some cases.

item.title: By: Daan Kortenbach
item.dc:creator: Daan Kortenbach
item.description: If you are using Chrome and just want to see if SPDY is working, you can also use the SPDY Indicator extension. I suspect you would use your solution for automated checks?
item.content:encoded:
If you are using Chrome and just want to see if SPDY is working, you can also use the SPDY Indicator extension.
I suspect you would use your solution for automated checks?
